subject: statistics
title: Z-Tests: One-Sample, Two-Sample, and Proportions
contentHtml:
Z-tests are a fundamental tool in statistical hypothesis testing, allowing us to determine whether a sample is representative of a larger population.

Given a set of data, we can use Z-tests to compare the mean or proportion of our sample to a known value or another sample.
name: Standardized Normal Variable" },
intuition: The key insight here is that Z-tests rely on the Central Limit Theorem, which states that the sample mean will be approximately normally distributed for large enough samples. This allows us to standardize our data and compare it to a known value or another sample.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the effectiveness of different marketing strategies
Analyzing the impact of climate change on species populations
commonMistakes: Failing to check assumptions, such as normality or equal variances

subject: statistics
title: Z-Tests: One-Sample, Two-Sample, and Proportions
contentHtml:
Z-tests are a fundamental concept in mathematical statistics that allow us to make inferences about population parameters based on sample data.

Given a random sample from a normal distribution with known standard deviation, we can use z-tests to determine whether the sample mean is significantly different from a hypothesized value or another sample mean.
name: Z-statistic" },
intuition: The z-test is a powerful tool for making inferences about population means when the standard deviation is known. It's widely used in machine learning and AI applications to compare the performance of different models or evaluate the effectiveness of treatments.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the accuracy of two classification algorithms
commonMistakes: Failing to check assumptions, such as normality

subject: statistics
title: Z-Tests: A Statistical Tool for One-Sample and Two-Sample Problems
contentHtml:
Z-tests are a fundamental concept in statistical hypothesis testing, allowing us to determine whether a sample mean or proportion deviates significantly from a known population parameter.

In this card, we'll explore the intuition behind Z-tests, including one-sample and two-sample problems, as well as proportions. We'll also discuss common misconceptions and real-world applications, especially in machine learning and artificial intelligence.
intuition: A Z-test is essentially a statistical way to determine whether our sample mean or proportion is 'far away' from the known population parameter. This is useful in machine learning when we want to determine if our model's performance is significantly better than chance.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the average rating of a new restaurant versus an existing one
commonMistakes: Failing to check assumptions, such as normality or equal variances

subject: statistics
title: Z-Test Formula
contentHtml: The Z-test is a statistical test used to determine whether there is a significant difference between a sample mean and a known population mean.
name: Z-Test Formula
variants: [ {"latex": "[Two-sample Z-test: \(Z = \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{\sqrt{(\sigma_1^2/n_1) + (\sigma_2^2/n_2)}}]\)", "description": "Used to compare two sample means"} ] },
intuition: The Z-test is a powerful tool for comparing a sample mean to a known population mean. It's commonly used in quality control and manufacturing to ensure that the average quality of a product meets certain standards.
realWorldApplications: Comparing treatment effects in medical studies

Z-tests are a fundamental tool in statistical hypothesis testing.

They help us determine whether a sample mean or proportion is significantly different from a known population value.

subject: statistics
title: Z-Tests: One-Sample, Two-Sample, and Proportions
contentHtml:
Z-tests are a fundamental tool in statistical hypothesis testing.

They help us determine whether there's sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis or not.
name: Standardized Normal Variable" },
problemHtml: Suppose we want to test the mean weight of a sample of students against a known population mean.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Calculate the sample mean and standard deviation", "mathHtml": "\(\bar{x} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n x_i\)", "explanation": "This gives us a sense of the data's central tendency"}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Compare it to the known population mean", "mathHtml": "\(\bar{x} - \mu\)"}, "explanation": "We're looking for a significant difference"} ],
finalAnswer: Reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis" },
intuition: Z-tests are used when we want to compare a sample mean to a known population mean, and we have some idea of the standard deviation.

subject: statistics
title: Z-Test Formula
contentHtml: The Z-test is a statistical test used to determine whether there is a significant difference between a sample mean and a population mean.
name: Z-Test Formula" },
problemHtml: Suppose we want to test the average height of a sample of students against the known population mean. We have a sample size of 30, and the sample mean is 175 cm.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Calculate the standard deviation of the sample", "mathHtml": "\\[s = \\sqrt{\\frac{\\sum(x_i - \\bar{x})^2}{n-1}}\]", "explanation": "We need to know the variability of our sample"}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Calculate the Z-score", "mathHtml": "\\[Z = \\frac{\\bar{x} - \\mu}{\\sigma / \\sqrt{n}}\]", "explanation": "This gives us a measure of how many standard deviations away from the mean our sample mean is"} ],
intuition: The Z-test helps us determine whether our sample is representative of the population by comparing it to the known population mean.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, the Z-test can be used to evaluate the performance of a model on a test dataset.

subject: statistics
statementHtml: Test whether the average GPA of students at a university is less than 3.2. A random sample of 25 students has an average GPA of 3.05 with a standard deviation of 0.35.
hints: Start by identifying the null and alternative hypotheses
Recall that the z-test statistic is calculated as the difference between the sample mean and the population mean, divided by the standard error
Use the inverse normal distribution function to find the critical value
solutionHtml: Let's calculate the test statistic: \\(z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}} = \frac{3.05 - 3.2}{0.35 / \sqrt{25}} = -1.43\\ Next, we need to find the p-value using the inverse normal distribution function: \\(P(Z < -1.43) = 0.0754\\ Since this is a one-tailed test, we reject the null hypothesis if the p-value is less than our desired significance level (0.05). In this case, we reject the null hypothesis. ",

subject: statistics
statementHtml: Test whether the average height of a sample of students is significantly different from the known population mean of 175.5 cm.
hints: Start by identifying the null and alternative hypotheses.
Recall that the standard normal distribution (Z) is used for one-sample Z-tests.
Consider how to calculate the test statistic and its corresponding p-value.
solutionHtml:
To perform a one-sample Z-test, we need to calculate the sample mean, \(\bar{x}\), and the standard error of the mean, \(SE(\bar{x})\).

\[ \bar{x} = 172.1, SE(\bar{x}) = 2.5 \]

Next, we calculate the test statistic:

\[ Z = (\bar{x} - 175.5) / (SE(\bar{x})) = (-3.4) / (2.5) = -1.36 \]

The p-value is then calculated using a standard normal distribution table or calculator:

\[ p = P(Z < -1.36) = 0.0877 \]

Since the p-value is greater than our chosen significance level (e.g., 0.05), we fail to reject the null hypothesis.

",

subject: statistics
statementHtml: Determine whether there is a significant difference in the average exam scores between two groups of students using a one-sample Z-test.
hints: Start by identifying the null and alternative hypotheses.
Recall that the test statistic for a one-sample Z-test is the sample mean minus the population mean, divided by the standard error.
Use the inverse normal distribution function to find the critical value or p-value.
solutionHtml:
To solve this problem, we first need to identify the null and alternative hypotheses.

\(H_0: \mu = 75\) vs. \(H_a: \mu > 75\)

Next, we calculate the sample mean and standard deviation:

\(\bar{x} = 78,\ s = 2.5\)

The test statistic is then calculated as:

\(z = (\bar{x} - \mu) / (s / \sqrt{n}) = (78 - 75) / (2.5 / \sqrt{25}) = 1.6\)

Using the inverse normal distribution function, we find that the p-value is approximately 0.056.

Since the p-value is greater than our desired significance level of 0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis.

",

subject: statistics
statementHtml: Consider a random sample of size n from a normal distribution with unknown mean μ. Test the null hypothesis that the population mean is equal to a known value θ, against the alternative hypothesis that it's not. Use a Z-test.
hints: Start by calculating the sample mean and standard deviation.
Use these values to find the test statistic, which should be approximately normally distributed.
Compare this statistic to the critical value from the standard normal distribution table or calculator.
solutionHtml:
Let's work through an example.

We have a sample of size 25 with mean 10.2 and standard deviation 1.5. We want to test if the population mean is equal to 9, against the alternative that it's not.

First, we calculate the sample mean and standard deviation:

\(\bar{x} = \frac{252}{25} = 10.2\)
\(s = \sqrt{\frac{1}{24}\sum_{i=1}^{25}(x_i - \bar{x})^2} = 1.5\)

Next, we find the test statistic:

\(z = \frac{\bar{x} - θ}{\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}} = \frac{10.2-9}{\frac{1.5}{\sqrt{25}}} = 1.8\)

We compare this to the critical value from the standard normal distribution table or calculator:

\(z_{0.025} = 1.96\), so we reject the null hypothesis.

",

subject: statistics
title: Z-Test Example: One-Sample Problem
contentHtml: In this example, we'll walk through a one-sample Z-test problem step-by-step.
statementHtml:
Is the average height of students in a statistics class greater than 5'8"? We have a sample mean height of 5.85 with a standard deviation of 0.15 and a sample size of 30.

",
solutionHtml:
We'll go through each step to find the answer:

  • Step 1: State the null and alternative hypotheses
  • Step 2: Determine the test statistic
  • Step 3: Find the critical value or p-value
  • Step 4: Compare the result to the significance level
problemHtml:
We want to test if the average height of students is greater than 5'8".

",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "State the null and alternative hypotheses", "mathHtml": "\(\mu \leq 68 \) vs. \(\mu > 68 \)", "explanation": "We're testing if the average height is greater than 5'8"}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Determine the test statistic", "mathHtml": "\(z = (\bar{x} - \mu) / (\sigma / \sqrt{n})\)", "explanation": "The Z-statistic measures how many standard deviations our sample mean is from the population mean"}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Find the critical value or p-value", "mathHtml": "\(z = (5.85 - 68) / (0.15 / \sqrt{30})\)", "explanation": "We'll calculate the Z-statistic and look up the corresponding p-value"}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Compare the result to the significance level", "mathHtml": "\(p < 0.05\)", "explanation": "If our calculated p-value is less than 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis"} ],
intuition: The Z-test helps us determine if a sample mean is significantly different from a known population mean.
visualDescription: A diagram showing the standard normal distribution and the calculated Z-statistic would be helpful in visualizing the results
realWorldApplications: Comparing the effectiveness of different treatments in a medical study

subject: statistics
title: Z-Test Example: One-Sample Proportion
contentHtml: In this example, we'll apply a one-sample proportion Z-test to determine if the sample proportion of students who prefer coffee over tea is significantly different from the known population proportion.
statementHtml: Suppose we have a random sample of 100 students and 60 of them prefer coffee over tea. The known population proportion is 0.55. Is the sample proportion statistically significant?
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "State the null and alternative hypotheses", "mathHtml": "\(H_0: p = 0.55,\) \(H_a: p < 0.55\)", "explanation": "We're testing if the sample proportion is less than the known population proportion."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Calculate the sample proportion", "mathHtml": "\(p = \frac{60}{100} = 0.6\)", "explanation": "This is our best estimate of the true population proportion."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the standard error", "mathHtml": "\(\text{SE}(p) = \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} = \sqrt{\frac{0.6(1-0.6)}{100}}\approx 0.0485\)", "explanation": "This measures the variability of our sample proportion."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Calculate the Z-score", "mathHtml": "\(Z = \frac{p - H_0}{\text{SE}(p)} = \frac{0.6-0.55}{0.0485}\approx 2.04\)", "explanation": "This measures how many standard errors our sample proportion is away from the known population proportion."}, {"stepNumber": 5, "description": "Determine the p-value", "mathHtml": "\(p = \Phi(-2.04) \approx 0.0214\)", "explanation": "This is the probability of observing a Z-score at least as extreme as ours assuming the null hypothesis is true."}, {"stepNumber": 6, "description": "Make a decision", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "Since our p-value is less than the significance level (usually 0.05), we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the sample proportion is statistically significant."} ],
realWorldApplications: Analyzing survey results in marketing or social sciences

subject: statistics
title: Z-Test: One-Sample Proportion
contentHtml: In this example, we'll apply a one-sample proportion Z-test to determine if the observed proportion of students who prefer coffee over tea is significantly different from the expected proportion.
statementHtml: A survey of 100 students shows that 60 students prefer coffee over tea. Is this proportion significantly different from the expected proportion of 0.5?
solutionHtml: To solve this problem, we'll follow these steps:
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "State the null and alternative hypotheses", "mathHtml": "\(H_0: p = 0.5\), \(H_a: p < 0.5\)", "explanation": "We're testing if the observed proportion is less than the expected proportion." }, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Calculate the sample proportion", "mathHtml": "\(p = \frac{60}{100} = 0.6\)", "explanation": "This gives us an estimate of the true proportion." }, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the standard error", "mathHtml": "\(SE = \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} = \sqrt{\frac{0.6(1-0.6)}{100}}\approx 0.0485\)", "explanation": "This measures the variability of our sample proportion." }, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Calculate the Z-score", "mathHtml": "\(Z = \frac{\bar{x}-\mu}{SE} = \frac{0.6-0.5}{0.0485}\approx -1.64\)", "explanation": "This measures how many standard errors our sample proportion is away from the expected proportion." }, {"stepNumber": 5, "description": "Look up the Z-score in a table or use software to find the p-value", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "We'll assume the p-value is less than 0.05." } ],
intuition: The key insight here is that we're using a Z-test to compare our sample proportion to the expected proportion, and the p-value tells us the probability of observing this or more extreme results assuming the null hypothesis is true.

problem.statementHtml: Is there a significant difference in the proportion of students who prefer coffee over tea between two universities?

workedExample.problemHtml: A survey at University A shows that 60% of students prefer coffee, while a separate survey at University B shows that 55% of students prefer tea. Is there a significant difference in the proportion of students who prefer coffee over tea between these two universities?

steps.description: State the null and alternative hypotheses
steps.explanation: We're testing whether the proportion of students who prefer coffee is less than 57.5% at University B.

steps.description: Calculate the sample proportions and standard errors
steps.explanation: We calculate the sample proportions and standard errors for each university.
We calculate the Z-statistic by subtracting the null proportion from the sample proportions and dividing by the standard error.
We calculate the p-value using the Z-statistic and a standard normal distribution.
